rule_text:
The design must address all three types of heat transfer between the heat source (examples include but are not limited to: exhaust pipe, coolant hose/tube, Accumulator Container) and
the panel that the driver could contact (seat or floor):
a. Conduction Isolation by one of the following:
• No direct contact between the heat source and the panel
• A heat resistant, conduction isolation material with a minimum thickness of 8 mm
between the heat source and the panel
b. Convection Isolation by a minimum air gap of 25 mm between the heat source and the
panel
c. Radiation Isolation by one of the following:
• A solid metal heat shield with a minimum thickness of 0.4 mm
• Reflective foil or tape when combined with conduction insulation
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.1.6.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
a. Be of sufficiently thick, impermeable construction (minimum 3.175mm [.125”] single wall) to
   prevent puncture or crack propagation, or the tank must be surrounded by a crushproof
   box that meets these requirements.
b. Be equipped with a positive locking cap, vented to the atmosphere, which will allow no fuel 
   leakage in the event of a rollover.
c. Be vented with a flame arrester, such as a sintered bronze filter with a minimum diameter 
   of 3.2mm [.125”].
d. Be equipped with a tip-over valve that closes off both the vent and filler opening in the event 
   of a rollover.
e. Have all fuel lines, filters, pumps, and other fuel system components mounted above the 
   bottom-most portion of the fuel tank to minimize the risk of fuel spills due to ground 
   contact during a mishap.
f. Have no part of the fuel tank lower than the bottom edge of the wheels while the car is in 
   normal racing trim.
g. Not be pressurized during operation, except by the natural vapor pressure of the fuel itself.
h. Be isolated from the driver compartment by a metal bulkhead or by the car’s frame 
   structure with an attached fire-resistant shield.
i. Be located such that no fuel line or fitting passes through the driver compartment, unless 
   enclosed in a vented metal enclosure which is part of, and bonded at all points to, the main 
   structure of the vehicle..

All vehicles must have a Floor Closeout to prevent track debris from entering. The Floor Closeout must extend from the foot area to the firewall. The panel(s) must be made of a solid non-brittle material. If multiple panels are used, gaps between panels must not exceed 3 mm.

rule_text:
a. 5 Point Harness – consists of two Lap Belts, two Shoulder Belts and one Anti-Submarine
Belt.
b. 6 Point Harness – consists of two Lap Belts, two Shoulder Belts and two leg or Anti-
Submarine Belts.
c. 7 Point Harness – consists of two Lap Belts, two Shoulder Belts, two leg or Anti-
Submarine Belts and a negative g or Z Belt.
d. Upright Driving Position - with a seat back angled at 30° or less from the vertical as
measured along the line joining the two 200 mm circles of the template of the 95th
percentile male as defined in F.5.6.4 and positioned per F.5.6.5

measured along the line joining the two 200 mm circles of the template of the 95th
percentile male as defined in F.5.6.4 and positioned per F.5.6.5

Belts from the chest to the release buckle.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.2.5.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
T.2.5.4 

Harness Requirements
Vehicles with a Reclined Driving Position must have: 
a. A 6 Point Harness or a 7 Point Harness
b. Anti-Submarine Belts with tilt lock adjusters (“quick adjusters”) OR two sets of Anti-
Submarine Belts installed. 
All Lap Belts must incorporate a tilt lock adjuster (“quick adjuster”).
Lap Belts with “pull-up” adjusters are recommended over “pull-down” adjusters. 

The Shoulder Belts must be the over the shoulder type. Only separate shoulder straps are
permitted. “Y” type shoulder straps are not allowed. The “H” type configuration is allowed. 
Belt Strap and Harness Installation - General 
The Lap Belt Shoulder Belts and Anti-Submarine Belt(s) must be securely mounted to the
Primary Structure. 
Any guide or support for the belts must be material meeting F.3.2.1.j
Each tab or bracket to which any part of the Harness is attached must: 
a. Support a minimum load in pullout and tearout before failure of: 
•  If one belt is attached to the tab or bracket 15 kN
•  If two belts are attached to the tab or bracket 30 kN
b. Be 1.6 mm minimum thickness
c.  Not be in bending when the attached part of the Harness is put under load 
d. Not cause abrasion to the belt webbing 
Attachment of tabs or brackets must meet the following: 
a. Where brackets are fastened to the chassis no less than two 6 mm or 1/4” minimum
diameter Critical Fasteners see T.8.2 or stronger must be used to attach the bracket to
the chassis. 
b. Where a single shear tab is welded to the chassis the tab to tube welding must be on
both sides of the base of the tab. 
Double shear attachments are preferred. Tabs and brackets for double shear mounts should
be welded on both sides. 

Harness installation must meet T.1.8.1
Lap Belt Mounting 
The Lap Belts must pass around the pelvic area below the Anterior Superior Iliac Spines (the
hip bones) 
Installation of the Lap Belts must go in a straight line from the mounting point until they reach
the driver's body without touching any hole in the seat or any other intermediate structure
The seat must be rolled or grommeted where the Belts or Harness pass through a hole in the
seat 
With an Upright Driving Position: 
a. The Lap Belt Side View Angle must be between 45° and 65° to the horizontal. 
b. The centerline of the Lap Belt at the seat bottom should be between 0 – 75 mm forward
of the seat back to seat bottom junction.

response:
F.5.6.4  Driver Template
A two dimensional template used to represent the 95th percentile male is made to the
following dimensions (see figure below):
•  A circle of diameter 200 mm will represent the hips and buttocks. 
•  A circle of diameter 200 mm will represent the shoulder/cervical region. 
•  A circle of diameter 300 mm will represent the head (with helmet).
•  A straight line measuring 490 mm will connect the centers of the two 200 mm circles. 
•  A straight line measuring 280 mm will connect the centers of the upper 200 mm circle
and the 300 mm head circle.

View Angle up to 20° rearwards. The Anti-Submarine Belt Mount Spacing should be
approximately 100 mm apart.

up around the groin to the release buckle.

rule_text: A Head Restraint must be provided to limit the rearward motion of the driver’s head.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.2.8.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: A Head Restraint must be provided to limit the rearward motion of the driver’s head. The Head Restraint must be vertical or near vertical in side view. All material and structure of the Head Restraint must be inside one or both of: a. Rollover Protection Envelope F.1.13 b. Head Restraint Protection (if used) F.5.10 The Head Restraint attachment and mounting must be strong enough to withstand a minimum force of: a. 900 N applied in a rearward direction b. 300 N applied in a lateral or vertical direction For all drivers the Head Restraint must be located and adjusted where: a. The Head Restraint is no more than 25 mm away from the back of the driver’s helmet with the driver in their normal driving position. b. The contact point of the back of the driver’s helmet on the Head Restraint is no less than 50 mm from any edge of the Head Restraint.

Body panels or other existing covers are acceptable when constructed per T.5.2.7 / T.5.2.8
Frame Members or existing components that exceed the scatter shield material requirements
may be used as part of the shield. 
Scatter shields may be composed of multiple pieces. Any gaps must be small (< 3 mm)

Chain Drive - Scatter shields for chains must:

b. Have a minimum width equal to three times the width of the chain
c.  Be centered on the center line of the chain 
d. Stay aligned with the chain under all conditions.

The Brake Pedal must be one of: 
•  Fabricated from steel or aluminum 
•  Machined from steel aluminum or titanium
The Brake Pedal and associated components design must withstand a minimum force of 2000
N without any failure of the Brake System pedal box chassis mounting or pedal adjustment
This is not a design criteria. The Brake Pedal and Brake System may be tested by pressing the
pedal with the maximum force that can be exerted by any official when seated normally.

response:
Failure of non-loadbearing components in the Brake System or pedal box must not interfere with Brake Pedal operation or Brake System function

b. The remaining Brake Pedal travel must directly actuate the hydraulic brake system.

rule_text: The vehicle must have a Brake Light that is clearly visible from the rear in very bright sunlight.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.3.4.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
The vehicle must have a Brake Light that is clearly visible from the rear in very bright sunlight. The Brake Light must be: 
a. Red in color on a Black background 
b. Rectangular triangular or near round shape with a minimum shining surface of 15 cm2

c. Mounted between the wheel centerline and driver’s shoulder level vertically and approximately on vehicle centerline laterally. 
When LED lights are used without a diffuser they must not be more than 20 mm apart. 
If a single line of LEDs is used the minimum length is 150 mm.

rule_text: Two or more electrically separate sensors must be used as APPSs. A single OEM type APPS with two completely separate sensors in a single housing is acceptable.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.4.2.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: T.4.2.2  Two or more electrically separate sensors must be used as APPSs. A single OEM type APPS with two completely separate sensors in a single housing is acceptable.

rule_text:
The APPS sensors must have different transfer functions which meet one of the two: • Each sensor has different gradients and/or offsets to the other(s). The circuit must have
a pull-up or pull-down resistor to bring an open circuit input to 0% Pedal Travel
• An OEM pedal sensor with opposite slopes. Non OEM opposite slope sensor
configurations require prior approval.
The intent is that in a short circuit the APPSs will only agree at 0% Pedal Travel

•  An OEM pedal sensor with opposite slopes. Non OEM opposite slope sensor
configurations require prior approval. 
The intent is that in a short circuit the APPSs will only agree at 0% Pedal Travel.

rule_text:
When an analogue signal is used, the APPS will be considered to have failed when they achieve an open circuit or short circuit condition which generates a signal outside of the
normal operating range, for example <0.5 V or >4.5 V.
The circuitry used to evaluate the sensor must use pull down or pull up resistors to ensure
that open circuit signals result in a failure being detected.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.4.2.10 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.

The circuitry used to evaluate the sensor must use pull down or pull up resistors to ensure that open circuit signals result in a failure being detected.

rule_text:
When any kind of digital data transmission is used to transmit the APPS signal, a. The ETC Systems Form must contain a detailed description of all the potential failure
modes that can occur, the strategy that is used to detect these failures and the tests that
have been conducted to prove that the detection strategy works.
b. The failures to be considered must include but are not limited to the failure of the APPS,
APPS signals being out of range, corruption of the message and loss of messages and the
associated time outs.

b. Must be made of material sufficient to resist finger forces. 
c. Mesh or perforated material may be used but must prevent the passage of a 12 mm
diameter object through the guard.

rule_text:

If lower grade aluminum alloy is used, then the material must be thicker to provide an
equivalent strength.

rule_text: The vehicle must have separate containers (catch cans) to retain fluids from any vents from the powertrain systems.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.5.6.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
The vehicle must have separate containers (catch cans) to retain fluids from any vents from the powertrain systems. 
Catch cans must be: 
a. Capable of containing boiling water without deformation
b. Located rearwards of the Firewall below the driver’s shoulder level 
c.  Positively retained using no tie wraps or tape
Catch cans for the engine coolant system and engine lubrication system must have a minimum capacity of 10% of the fluid being contained or 0.9 liter whichever is higher.

rule_text:
Any system on the vehicle that uses a compressed gas as an actuating medium must meet the
following:
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.6.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
T.6.1  Compressed Gas Cylinders and Lines

T.6.1.1

Any system on the vehicle that uses a compressed gas as an actuating medium must meet the following:
Working Gas - The working gas must be non flammable
T.6.1.2

Cylinder Certification - The gas cylinder/tank must be commercially manufactured designed and built for the pressure being used certified by an accredited testing laboratory in the country of its origin and labeled or stamped appropriately.
T.6.1.3

Pressure Regulation - The pressure regulator must be mounted directly onto the gas cylinder/tank
T.6.1.4

Lines and Fittings - The gas lines and fittings must be appropriate for the maximum possible operating pressure of the system.

rule_text:
Aerodynamic Device A part on the vehicle which guides airflow for purposes including generation of downforce
and/or change of drag.

designed to meet this requirement.

rule_text: Other edges that a person may touch must not be sharp

rule_text:

suspension components are allowed.

rule_text:

relative to the forward direction, along the top, sides and bottom of all affected edges.

restraint support, excluding any padding, set (if adjustable) in its fully rearward position

Location

rule_text:
Rear Aerodynamic Zone The volume that is:
• Rearward of the Head Restraint Plane
• Inboard of two vertical planes parallel to the centerline of the chassis touching the inside
of the rear tires at the height of the hub centerline
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.7.3.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.

rule_text: Any part of any Aerodynamic Device or Bodywork must meet V.1.1 and V.1.4.1
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.7.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
F.7.4

Composite monocoques must: 
a. Meet the materials requirements in F.4 Composite and Other Materials 
b. Use data from the laminate testing results as the basis for any strength or stiffness calculations 

Front Bulkhead
When modeled as an “L” shaped section the EI of the Front Bulkhead about both vertical and lateral axis must be equivalent to that of the tubes specified for the Front Bulkhead per F.6.1
The length of the section perpendicular to the Front Bulkhead may be a maximum of 25 mm measured from the rearmost face of the Front Bulkhead 
Any Front Bulkhead which supports the IA plate must have a perimeter shear strength equivalent to a 1.5 mm thick steel plate

Front Bulkhead Support
In addition to proving that the strength of the monocoque is sufficient, the monocoque must have equivalent EI to the sum of the EI of the six Steel Tubes (F.3.2.1.b) that it replaces. 
The EI of the vertical side of the Front Bulkhead support structure must be equivalent to or more than the EI of one steel tube that it replaces when calculated as per F.4.4
The perimeter shear strength of the monocoque laminate in the Front Bulkhead support structure must be 4 kN or more for a section with a diameter of 25 mm. 
This must be proven by a physical test completed per F.4.3.5 and the results included in the SES. 

Front Hoop Attachment
The Front Hoop must be mechanically attached to the monocoque 
a. Front Hoop Mounting Plates must be the minimum thickness of the Front Hoop F.3.2.1.c
b. The Front Hoop tube must be mechanically connected to the Mounting Plate with Mounting Plates parallel to both sides of the tube with gussets from the Front Hoop tube along both sides of the mounting plate
Front Hoop attachment to a monocoque must obey F.5.7.2 or F.7.8 within 25 mm of any bends and nodes that are not at the top center of the Front Hoop 
The Front Hoop may be fully laminated into the monocoque if: 
a. The Front Hoop has core fit tightly around its entire circumference. Expanding foam is not permitted
b. Equivalence to six or more mounts compliant with F.7.8 must show in the SES
c.  A small gap in the laminate (approximately 25 mm) exists for inspection of the Front Hoop F.5.7.6
Adhesive must not be the sole method of attaching the Front Hoop to the monocoque.

rule_text:
In plan view, any part of any Aerodynamic Device must be:
a. No more than 700 mm forward of the fronts of the front tires
b. No more than 250 mm rearward of the rear of the rear tires
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.7.5 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
F.7.5.3.b

No openings in Side View between the Front Hoop and Main Hoop.

rule_text: In plan view, any part of any Aerodynamic Device must be:
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.7.6 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
F.7.6
F.7.6.1

The Main Hoop must be mechanically attached to the monocoque 

a. Main Hoop mounting plates must be 2.0 mm minimum thickness steel 

b. The Main Hoop tube must be mechanically connected to the mounting plate with 2.0 mm minimum thickness steel plates parallel to both sides of the tube with gussets from the Main Hoop tube along both sides of the mounting plate

F.7.6.2

Main Hoop attachment to a monocoque must obey F.7.8 within 25 mm of any bends and nodes that are below the top of the monocoque.

rule_text:
When forward of the centerline of the front wheel axles: Inboard of two vertical planes parallel to the centerline of the chassis touching the outside of
the front tires at the height of the hubs.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.7.6.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: The Side Impact Zone must have Equivalence to the three (3) Steel Tubes (F.3.2.1.e) that it replaces.

rule_text:
When between the centerlines of the front and rear wheel axles: Inboard of a line drawn connecting the outer surfaces of the front and rear tires at the height
of the wheel centers
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.7.6.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
F.7.6.2

Main Hoop attachment to a monocoque must obey F.7.8 within 25 mm of any bends and nodes that are below the top of the monocoque.

rule_text: When rearward of the centerline of the rear wheel axles: In the Rear Aerodynamic Zone
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.7.6.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: All forward facing edges on the Bodywork that could contact people including the nose must have forward facing radii minimum 38 mm. This minimum radius must extend 45° or more relative to the forward direction along the top sides and bottom of all affected edges.

rule_text:
Any part of any Aerodynamic Device that is located: a. In the Rear Aerodynamic Zone must be no higher than 1200 mm above the ground
b. Outside of the Rear Aerodynamic Zone must be no higher than 500 mm above the
ground
c. Forward of the centerline of the front wheel axles and outboard of two vertical planes
parallel to the centerline of the chassis touching the inside of the front tires at the height
of the hubs must be no higher than 250 mm above the ground
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.7.7.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: All forward facing edges on the Bodywork that could contact people including the nose must have forward facing radii minimum 38 mm. This minimum radius must extend 45° or more relative to the forward direction along the top sides and bottom of all affected edges.

rule_text:
Bodywork height is not restricted when the Bodywork is located: • Between the transverse vertical planes positioned at the front and rear axle centerlines
• Inside two vertical fore and aft planes 400 mm outboard from the centerline on each
side of the vehicle
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.7.7.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.7.7.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words..

response: T.8.1 Critical Fasteners.

rule_text:
Any Critical Fastener must meet, at minimum, one of the following: a. SAE Grade 5
b. Metric Class 8.8
c. AN/MS Specifications
d. Equivalent to or better than above, as approved by a Rules Question or at Technical
Inspection
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.8.2.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.

F.8.2.1  The Anti Intrusion Plate must be one of the following: 
a. 1.5 mm minimum thickness solid steel

rule_text:

• Hexagonal recessed drive (Socket Head Cap Screws or Allen screws/bolts)

rule_text: A minimum of two full threads must project from any lock nut.

response: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.8.2.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words..

rule_text: Some Critical Fastener applications have additional requirements that are provided in the applicable section.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.8.2.5 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
If the Impact Attenuator is attached by bolting: 
a. Must have no less than eight 8 mm or 5/16” minimum diameter Critical Fasteners T.8.2
b. The distance between any two bolt centers must be 50 mm minimum
c. Each bolt attachment must have pullout tearout and bending capabilities of 15 kN
d. Must be bolted directly to the Primary Structure.

rule_text:
Positive Locking Mechanisms are defined as those which: a. Technical Inspectors / team members can see that the device/system is in place (visible).
b. Do not rely on the clamping force to apply the locking or anti vibration feature.
Meaning If the fastener begins to loosen, the locking device still prevents the fastener coming
completely loose
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.8.3.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
Composite Anti Intrusion Plates: 
a. Must not fail in a frontal impact 
b. Must withstand a minimum static load of 120 kN distributed over the 200 mm x 100 mm
minimum Impact Attenuator area
Strength of the Composite Anti Intrusion Plate must be verified by one of the two methods: 
a. Physical testing of the AIP attached to a structurally representative section of the
intended chassis 
•  The test fixture must have equivalent strength and stiffness to a baseline front
bulkhead or must be the same as the first 50 mm of the Chassis 
•  Test data is valid for only one Competition Year
b. Laminate material testing under F.4.3.2 and F.4.3.5 and calculations of 3 point bending
and perimeter shear.

rule_text:
Examples of acceptable Positive Locking Mechanisms include, but are not limited to: a. Correctly installed safety wiring
b. Cotter pins
c. Nylon lock nuts (where temperature does not exceed 80°C)
d. Prevailing torque lock nuts
Lock washers, bolts with nylon patches and thread locking compounds (Loctite®), DO NOT
meet the positive locking requirement.

response:
Composite Anti Intrusion Plates: 
a. Must not fail in a frontal impact

minimum Impact Attenuator area
Strength of the Composite Anti Intrusion Plate must be verified by one of the two methods: 
a. Physical testing of the AIP attached to a structurally representative section of the
intended chassis 
•  The test fixture must have equivalent strength and stiffness to a baseline front
bulkhead or must be the same as the first 50 mm of the Chassis 
•  Test data is valid for only one Competition Year
b. Laminate material testing under F.4.3.2 and F.4.3.5.

rule_text: Adjustable tie rod ends must be constrained with a jam nut to prevent loosening.

GR.9.2.1 Competition Year
The period beginning at the event of the Formula SAE series where the vehicle first competes and continuing until the start of the corresponding event held approximately 12 months later.

response: T.9.2.2  All Low Voltage batteries must have Overcurrent Protection that trips at or below the maximum specified discharge current of the cells.

rule_text: Each Master Switch ( IC.9.3 / EV.7.9 ) must meet the following:
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.9.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
T.9.3 Master Switches 
Each Master Switch ( IC.9.3 / EV.7.9 ) must meet the following: 
Location
a. On the driver’s right hand side of the vehicle
b. In proximity to the Main Hoop
c.  At the driver's shoulder height 
d. Able to be easily actuated from outside the vehicle
Characteristics
a. Be of the rotary mechanical type 
b. Be rigidly mounted to the vehicle and must not be removed during maintenance
c.  Mounted where the rotary axis of the key is near horizontal and across the vehicle
d. The ON position must be in the horizontal position and must be marked accordingly 
e. The OFF position must be clearly marked 
f.  (EV Only) Operated with a red removable key that must only be removable in the
electrically open position.

Location a. On the driver’s right hand side of the vehicle

rule_text:
Inertia Switch Requirement • (EV) Must have an Inertia Switch
• (IC) Should have an Inertia Switch
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.9.4.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
T.9.4.1 Each Master Switch ( IC.9.3 / EV.7.9 ) must meet the following: 
Location
a. On the driver’s right hand side of the vehicle
b. In proximity to the Main Hoop
c. At the driver's shoulder height 
d. Able to be easily actuated from outside the vehicle
Characteristics
a. Be of the rotary mechanical type 
b. Be rigidly mounted to the vehicle and must not be removed during maintenance
c. Mounted where the rotary axis of the key is near horizontal and across the vehicle
d. The ON position must be in the horizontal position and must be marked accordingly 
e. The OFF position must be clearly marked 
f. (EV Only) Operated with a red removable key that must only be removable in the electrically open position.

rule_text:
The Inertia Switch must be: a. A Sensata Resettable Crash Sensor or equivalent
b. Mechanically and rigidly attached to the vehicle
c. Removable to test functionality
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.9.4.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
IC.2.4.2 The only allowed sequence of components are the following: 
a. For naturally aspirated engines the sequence must be: throttle body restrictor and
engine. 
b. For turbocharged or supercharged engines the sequence must be: restrictor.

rule_text:
Inertia Switch operation: a. Must trigger due to a longitudinal impact load which decelerates the vehicle at between
8 g and 11 g depending on the duration of the deceleration (refer to spec sheet of the
Sensata device)
b. Must Open the Shutdown Circuit IC.9.2.2 / EV.7.2.2 if triggered
c. Must latch until manually reset
d. May be reset by the driver from inside the driver's cell
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.9.4.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
Master Switches 
Each Master Switch ( IC.9.3 / EV.7.9 ) must meet the following: 
Location
a. On the driver’s right hand side of the vehicle
b. In proximity to the Main Hoop
c.  At the driver's shoulder height 
d. Able to be easily actuated from outside the vehicle
Characteristics
a. Be of the rotary mechanical type 
b. Be rigidly mounted to the vehicle and must not be removed during maintenance
c.  Mounted where the rotary axis of the key is near horizontal and across the vehicle
d. The ON position must be in the horizontal position and must be marked accordingly 
e. The OFF position must be clearly marked 
f.  (EV Only) Operated with a red removable key that must only be removable in the
electrically open position 
Inertia Switch
Inertia Switch Requirement 
•  (EV) Must have an Inertia Switch
•  (IC) Should have an Inertia Switch
The Inertia Switch must be: 
a. A Sensata Resettable Crash Sensor or equivalent 
b. Mechanically and rigidly attached to the vehicle
c.  Removable to test functionality
Inertia Switch operation: 
a. Must trigger due to a longitudinal impact load which decelerates the vehicle at between
8 g and 11 g depending on the duration of the deceleration (refer to spec sheet of the
Sensata device) 
b. Must Open the Shutdown Circuit IC.9.2.2 / EV.7.2.2 if triggered
c.  Must latch until manually reset 
d. May be reset by the driver from inside the driver's cell.

rule_text:
The assigned vehicle number must appear on the vehicle as follows: a. Locations: in three places, on the front of the chassis and both sides
b. Height: 150 mm minimum
c. Font: Block numbers (sans serif characters without italic, outline, shadow, or cursive
numbers)
d. Stroke Width and Spacing between numbers: 18 mm minimum
e. Color: White numbers on a black background OR black numbers on a white background
f. Background: round, oval, square or rectangular
g. Spacing: 25 mm minimum between the edge of the numbers and the edge of the
background
h. The numbers must not be obscured by parts of the vehicle
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule VE.1.1.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
VE.1.1.1 The assigned vehicle number must appear on the vehicle as follows: 
a. Locations: in three places on the front of the chassis and both sides
b. Height: 150 mm minimum
c.  Font: Block numbers (sans serif characters without italic outline shadow or cursive
numbers) 
d. Stroke Width and Spacing between numbers: 18 mm minimum
e. Color: White numbers on a black background OR black numbers on a white background
f.  Background: round oval square or rectangular.

rule_text: Additional letters or numerals must not show before or after the vehicle number
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule VE.1.1.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: VE.1.1.2 Additional letters or numerals must not show before or after the vehicle number.

rule_text:
Each vehicle must clearly display the school name.
a. Abbreviations are allowed if unique and generally recognized
b. The name must be in Roman characters minimum 50 mm high on both sides of the
vehicle.
c. The characters must be placed on a high contrast background in an easily visible location.
d. The school name may also appear in non Roman characters, but the Roman character
version must be uppermost on the sides.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule VE.1.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.

The SAE International Logo must be displayed on the front and/or both sides of the vehicle in
a prominent location.

The SAE International Logo must be displayed on the front and/or both sides of the vehicle in
a prominent location.

rule_text:

• Located on the upper front surface of the nose along the vehicle centerline

•  A clear and unobstructed area minimum 25 cm wide x 20 cm high

rule_text: A Jacking Point must be provided at the rear of the vehicle
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule VE.2.1.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: VE.2.1.1 A Jacking Point must be provided at the rear of the vehicle.

rule_text:
The Jacking Point must be: a. Capable of supporting the vehicle weight and of engaging the organizer Quick Jacks
b. Visible to a person standing 1 m behind the vehicle
c. Color: Orange
d. Oriented laterally and perpendicular to the centerline of the vehicle
e. Made from round, 25 - 30 mm OD aluminum or steel tube
f. Exposed around the lower 180° of its circumference over a minimum length of 280 mm
g. Access from the rear of the tube must be unobstructed for 300 mm or more of its length
h. The height of the tube must allow 75 mm minimum clearance from the bottom of the
tube to the ground
i. When the vehicle is raised to where the bottom of the tube is 200 mm above ground, the
wheels do not touch the ground when they are in full rebound
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule VE.2.1.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
VE.2.1.2 The Jacking Point must be: 
a. Capable of supporting the vehicle weight and of engaging the organizer Quick Jacks 
b. Visible to a person standing 1 m behind the vehicle
c. Color: Orange
d. Oriented laterally and perpendicular to the centerline of the vehicle
e. Made from round 25 - 30 mm OD aluminum or steel tube 
f. Exposed around the lower 180° of its circumference over a minimum length of 280 mm 
g. Access from the rear of the tube must be unobstructed for 300 mm or more of its length
h. The height of the tube must allow 75 mm minimum clearance from the bottom of the
tube to the ground
i. When the vehicle is raised to where the bottom of the tube is 200 mm above ground the
wheels do not touch the ground when they are in full rebound.

rule_text:
Each vehicle must have a removable device which attaches to the rear of the vehicle that:
a. Allows two people, standing erect behind the vehicle, to push the vehicle around the
competition site
b. Is capable of slowing and stopping the forward motion of the vehicle and pulling it
rearwards

b. Is capable of slowing and stopping the forward motion of the vehicle and pulling it rearwards.

rule_text:
Each team must have two or more fire extinguishers. a. One extinguisher must readily be available in the team’s paddock area
b. One extinguisher must accompany the vehicle when moved using the push bar
A commercially available on board fire system may be used instead of the fire
extinguisher that accompanies the vehicle
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule VE.2.3.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.

rule_text: Hand held fire extinguishers must NOT be mounted on or in the vehicle
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule VE.2.3.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.

rule_text:
Each fire extinguisher must meet the following: a. Capacity: 0.9 kg (2 lbs)
b. Working Medium: Dry chemical/dry powder. Aqueous Film Forming Foam (AFFF) and
Halon extinguishers and systems are prohibited.
c. Equipped with a manufacturer installed pressure/charge gauge.
d. Minimum acceptable ratings:
• USA, Canada & Brazil: 10BC or 1A 10BC
• Europe: 34B or 5A 34B
• Australia: 20BE or 1A 10BE
e. Extinguishers of larger capacity (higher numerical ratings) are acceptable.

b. Working Medium: Dry chemical/dry powder. Aqueous Film Forming Foam (AFFF) and Halon extinguishers and systems are prohibited. 
c.  Equipped with a manufacturer installed pressure/charge gauge.

rule_text: The body of a camera or recording unit that weighs more than 0.25 kg must be secured at a minimum of two points on different sides of the camera body.

rule_text: If a tether is used to restrain the camera, the tether length must be limited to prevent contact with the driver.

response: VE.2.5.5 If a tether is used to restrain the camera the tether length must be limited to prevent contact with the driver.

rule_text:
Any Driver Equipment: a. Must be in good condition with no tears, rips, open seams, areas of significant wear,
abrasions or stains which might compromise performance.
b. Must fit properly
c. May be inspected at any time
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule VE.3.1.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
VE.3.1.1 Any Driver Equipment: 
a. Must be in good condition with no tears rips open seams areas of significant wear 
abrasions or stains which might compromise performance. 
b. Must fit properly 
c. May be inspected at any time.

rule_text:

Polybenzimidazole (common name PBI) and Proban.

For this section some but not all of the approved materials are: Carbon X Indura Nomex 
Polybenzimidazole (common name PBI) and Proban.

rule_text:

made from nylon or any other synthetic material which could melt when exposed to high heat
are prohibited.

rule_text:

b. Contains an integrated visor/face shield supplied with the helmet
c. Meets an approved standard
d. Is properly labeled for that standard

rule_text: The driver must wear the following:
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule VE.3.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
VE.3.3  Driver Gear
The driver must wear the following: 
VE.3.3.1 Driver Suit
A one piece suit made from a minimum of two layers of Flame Resistant Material that covers
the body from the neck to the ankles and the wrists.

rule_text:
Driver Suit A one piece suit, made from a minimum of two layers of Flame Resistant Material that covers
the body from the neck to the ankles and the wrists.
Each suit must meet one or more of the following standards and be labeled as such:
• SFI 3.2A/5 (or higher ex: /10, /15, /20)
• SFI 3.4/5 (or higher ex: /10, /15, /20)
• FIA Standard 1986
• FIA Standard 8856-2000
• FIA Standard 8856-2018
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule VE.3.3.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
VE.3.3.1 Driver Suit
A one piece suit made from a minimum of two layers of Flame Resistant Material that covers
the body from the neck to the ankles and the wrists.

rule_text:
Underclothing All competitors should wear fire retardant underwear (long pants and long sleeve shirt) under
their approved Driver Suit.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule VE.3.3.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.

VE.3.3.2 Underclothing
All competitors should wear fire retardant underwear (long pants and long sleeve shirt) under
their approved Driver Suit.

rule_text:
Balaclava A Balaclava (head sock) which covers the driver’s head, hair and neck, made from Flame
Resistant Material

A Balaclava (head sock) which covers the driver’s head hair and neck made from Flame
Resistant Material.

and the Shoes.

Socks made from Flame Resistant Material that cover the bare skin between the driver’s suit

Gloves of all leather construction or fire retardant gloves constructed using leather palms with

rule_text:
Arm Restraints a. Arm restraints must be worn in a way that the driver can release them and exit the
vehicle unassisted regardless of the vehicle’s position.
b. Arm restraints must be commercially manufactured. Arm restraints certified to SFI Spec
3.3 and labeled as such meet this requirement.

response:
VE.3.3.7 Arm Restraints
a. Arm restraints must be worn in a way that the driver can release them and exit the
vehicle unassisted regardless of the vehicle’s position. 
b. Arm restraints must be commercially manufactured. Arm restraints certified to SFI Spec
3.3 and labeled as such meet this requirement.

rule_text:
The engine(s) used to power the vehicle must: a. Be a piston engine(s) using a four stroke primary heat cycle
b. Have a total combined displacement less than or equal to 710 cc per cycle.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.1.1.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
IC.1.1.1 The engine(s) used to power the vehicle must: 
a. Be a piston engine(s) using a four stroke primary heat cycle 
b. Have a total combined displacement less than or equal to 710 cc per cycle.

rule_text: Hybrid powertrains, such as those using electric motors running off stored energy, are prohibited.

response: Hybrid powertrains such as those using electric motors running off stored energy are prohibited.

rule_text: All waste/rejected heat from the primary heat cycle may be used. The method of conversion is not limited to the four stroke cycle.

rule_title: Air Intake and Fuel System Location
rule_text:
All parts of the engine air system and fuel control, delivery and storage systems (including the
throttle or carburetor, and the complete air intake system, including the air cleaner and any
air boxes) must lie inside the Tire Surface Envelope F.1.14
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.1.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
IC.1.2  Air Intake and Fuel System Location
All parts of the engine air system and fuel control delivery and storage systems (including the
throttle or carburetor and the complete air intake system including the air cleaner and any
air boxes) must lie inside the Tire Surface Envelope F.1.14.

rule_text: The Intake System must meet IC.1.2
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.2.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: The Intake System must meet IC.1.2.

rule_text: Any portion of the air intake system that is less than 350 mm above the ground must be shielded from side or rear impacts by structure built per F.6.4 / F.7.5 as applicable.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.2.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: Any portion of the air intake system that is less than 350 mm above the ground must be shielded from side or rear impacts by structure built per F.6.4 / F.7.5 as applicable.

rule_text:
The intake manifold must be securely attached to the engine block or cylinder head with brackets and mechanical fasteners.
• Hose clamps, plastic ties, or safety wires do not meet this requirement.
• The use of rubber bushings or hose is acceptable for creating and sealing air passages,
but is not a structural attachment.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.3.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
Each attachment point requires no less than two 8 mm or 5/16” minimum diameter Critical Fasteners see T.8.2 Each attachment point requires backing plates which meet one of: 
•  Steel with a minimum thickness of 2 mm
•  Alternate materials if Equivalency is approved
The Front Hoop Bracing Main Hoop Bracing and Main Hoop Bracing Supports may use only one 10 mm or 3/8” minimum diameter Critical Fasteners see T.8.2 as an alternative to F.7.8.5 above if the bolt is on the centerline of the bracing tube to prevent loading the bolt in bending similar to the figure below.

rule_text: Threaded fasteners used to secure and/or seal the intake manifold must have a Positive Locking Mechanism, see T.8.3.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.3.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
All Lap Belts must incorporate a tilt lock adjuster (“quick adjuster”).
Lap Belts with “pull-up” adjusters are recommended over “pull-down” adjusters.

rule_text:
Intake systems with significant mass or cantilever from the cylinder head must be supported to prevent stress to the intake system.
a. Supports to the engine must be rigid.
b. Supports to the Chassis must incorporate some isolation to allow for engine movement
and chassis flex.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.3.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
T.2.3.3

All Lap Belts must incorporate a tilt lock adjuster (“quick adjuster”).
Lap Belts with “pull-up” adjusters are recommended over “pull-down” adjusters.

rule_text: All airflow to the engine(s) must pass through a single circular restrictor placed in the intake system.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.4.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
IC.2.4.1  All airflow to the engine(s) must pass through a single circular restrictor placed in the intake
system.

rule_text:
The only allowed sequence of components are the following: a. For naturally aspirated engines, the sequence must be: throttle body, restrictor, and
engine.
b. For turbocharged or supercharged engines, the sequence must be: restrictor,
compressor, throttle body, engine.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.4.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
IC.2.4.2  The only allowed sequence of components are the following: 
a. For naturally aspirated engines the sequence must be: throttle body restrictor and
engine. 
b. For turbocharged or supercharged engines the sequence must be: restrictor 
compressor throttle body engine.

rule_text:
The maximum restrictor diameters at any time during the competition are: a. Gasoline fueled vehicles 20.0 mm
b. E85 fueled vehicles 19.0 mm
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.4.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: IC.4.3.3  Submit the ETC Notice of Intent and ETC Systems Form as given in section DR - Document Requirements.

rule_text: The restrictor must be located to facilitate measurement during Technical Inspection
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.4.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: F.11.2.4 Non Crushable Items mounted behind the Rear Impact structure must not be able to come through the Rear Impact structure.

rule_text: The circular restricting cross section must NOT be movable or flexible in any way
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.4.5 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
F.4.3.5  Perimeter Shear Test
a. The Perimeter Shear Test must be completed by measuring the force required to push or
pull a 25 mm diameter flat punch through a flat laminate sample. 
b. The sample must: 
•  Measure 100 mm x 100 mm minimum
•  Have core and skin thicknesses identical to those used in the actual application
•  Be manufactured using the same materials and processes

c.  The fixture must support the entire sample except for a 32 mm hole aligned coaxially
with the punch. 
d. The sample must not be clamped to the fixture
e. The edge of the punch and hole in the fixture may include an optional fillet up to a
maximum radius of 1 mm. 
f.  The SES must include force and displacement data and photos of the test setup. 
g. The first peak in the load-deflection curve must be used to determine the skin shear
strength; this may be less than the minimum force required by F.7.3.3 / F.7.5.5.

rule_text: The restrictor must not be part of the movable portion of a barrel throttle body.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.4.6 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
The Diagonal Side Impact Member must: 
a. Connect the Upper Side Impact Member and Lower Side Impact Member forward of the Main Hoop and rearward of the Front Hoop
b. Completely Triangulate the bays created by the Upper and Lower Side Impact Members.

rule_text:
The intake air may be cooled with an intercooler (a charge air cooler). a. It must be located downstream of the throttle body
b. Only ambient air may be used to remove heat from the intercooler system
c. Air to air and water to air intercoolers are permitted
d. The coolant of a water to air intercooler system must meet T.5.4.1
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.5.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
T.2.5.1

Harness Requirements
Vehicles with a Reclined Driving Position must have:
a. A 6 Point Harness or a 7 Point Harness
b. Anti-Submarine Belts with tilt lock adjusters (“quick adjusters”) OR two sets of Anti-Submarine Belts installed.
All Lap Belts must incorporate a tilt lock adjuster (“quick adjuster”).
Lap Belts with “pull-up” adjusters are recommended over “pull-down” adjusters..

rule_text: If pop-off valves, recirculation valves, or heat exchangers (intercoolers) are used, they must be positioned in the intake system as shown in IC.2.4.2.b
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.5.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: If pop-off valves, recirculation valves, or heat exchangers (intercoolers) are used, they must be positioned in the intake system as shown in IC.2.4.2.b.

rule_text:
Plenums must not be located anywhere upstream of the throttle body For the purpose of definition, a plenum is any tank or volume that is a significant enlargement
of the normal intake runner system. Teams may submit their designs via a Rules Question for
review prior to competition if the legality of their proposed system is in doubt.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.5.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
Turbochargers & Superchargers 
The intake air may be cooled with an intercooler (a charge air cooler).
a. It must be located downstream of the throttle body 
b. Only ambient air may be used to remove heat from the intercooler system 
c.  Air to air and water to air intercoolers are permitted 
d. The coolant of a water to air intercooler system must meet T.5.4.1
If pop-off valves recirculation valves or heat exchangers (intercoolers) are used they must be
positioned in the intake system as shown in IC.2.4.2.b
Plenums must not be located anywhere upstream of the throttle body
For the purpose of definition a plenum is any tank or volume that is a significant enlargement
of the normal intake runner system.

rule_text: The maximum allowable area of the inner diameter of the intake runner system between the restrictor and throttle body is 2825 mm2
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.5.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
T.2.5.4 

Harness Requirements
Vehicles with a Reclined Driving Position must have: 
a. A 6 Point Harness or a 7 Point Harness
b. Anti-Submarine Belts with tilt lock adjusters (“quick adjusters”) OR two sets of Anti-
Submarine Belts installed. 
All Lap Belts must incorporate a tilt lock adjuster (“quick adjuster”).
Lap Belts with “pull-up” adjusters are recommended over “pull-down” adjusters. 

The Shoulder Belts must be the over the shoulder type. Only separate shoulder straps are
permitted. “Y” type shoulder straps are not allowed. The “H” type configuration is allowed. 
Belt Strap and Harness Installation - General 
The Lap Belt Shoulder Belts and Anti-Submarine Belt(s) must be securely mounted to the
Primary Structure. 
Any guide or support for the belts must be material meeting F.3.2.1.j
Each tab or bracket to which any part of the Harness is attached must: 
a. Support a minimum load in pullout and tearout before failure of: 
•  If one belt is attached to the tab or bracket 15 kN
•  If two belts are attached to the tab or bracket 30 kN
b. Be 1.6 mm minimum thickness
c.  Not be in bending when the attached part of the Harness is put under load 
d. Not cause abrasion to the belt webbing 
Attachment of tabs or brackets must meet the following: 
a. Where brackets are fastened to the chassis no less than two 6 mm or 1/4” minimum
diameter Critical Fasteners see T.8.2 or stronger must be used to attach the bracket to
the chassis. 
b. Where a single shear tab is welded to the chassis the tab to tube welding must be on
both sides of the base of the tab. 
Double shear attachments are preferred. Tabs and brackets for double shear mounts should
be welded on both sides. 

Harness installation must meet T.1.8.1
Lap Belt Mounting 
The Lap Belts must pass around the pelvic area below the Anterior Superior Iliac Spines (the
hip bones) 
Installation of the Lap Belts must go in a straight line from the mounting point until they reach
the driver's body without touching any hole in the seat or any other intermediate structure
The seat must be rolled or grommeted where the Belts or Harness pass through a hole in the
seat 
With an Upright Driving Position: 
a. The Lap Belt Side View Angle must be between 45° and 65° to the horizontal. 
b. The centerline of the Lap Belt at the seat bottom should be between 0 – 75 mm forward
of the seat back to seat bottom junction.

rule_text:
Any crankcase or engine lubrication vent lines routed to the intake system must be connected
upstream of the intake system restrictor.

Fasteners see T.8.2
Each attachment point requires backing plates which meet one of:

The Front Hoop Bracing Main Hoop Bracing and Main Hoop Bracing Supports may use only
one 10 mm or 3/8” minimum diameter Critical Fasteners see T.8.2 as an alternative to F.7.8.5
above if the bolt is on the centerline of the bracing tube to prevent loading the bolt in
bending similar to the figure below.

b. Boosted applications must not use carburetors.

rule_text:
The throttle may be actuated:
a. Mechanically by a cable or rod system IC.3.3
b. By Electronic Throttle Control IC.4
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.3.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
Each attachment point requires no less than two 8 mm or 5/16” minimum diameter Critical Fasteners see T.8.2. Each attachment point requires backing plates which meet one of: 
•  Steel with a minimum thickness of 2 mm
•  Alternate materials if Equivalency is approved
The Front Hoop Bracing Main Hoop Bracing and Main Hoop Bracing Supports may use only one 10 mm or 3/8” minimum diameter Critical Fasteners see T.8.2 as an alternative to F.7.8.5 above if the bolt is on the centerline of the bracing tube to prevent loading the bolt in bending similar to the figure below.

rule_text:
The throttle cable or rod must: a. Have smooth operation
b. Have no possibility of binding or sticking
c. Be minimum 50 mm from any exhaust system component and out of the exhaust stream
d. Be protected from being bent or kinked by the driver’s foot when it is operated by the
driver or when the driver enters or exits the vehicle
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.3.3.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: V.3.3.1  In any angular position the Steering Wheel must meet T.1.4.4.

rule_text:
The throttle actuation system must use two or more return springs located at the throttle body.
Throttle Position Sensors (TPS) are NOT acceptable as return springs
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.3.3.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: V.3.3.2  The Steering Wheel must be attached to the column with a quick disconnect.

rule_text:
Failure of any component of the throttle system must not prevent the throttle returning to the closed position.
This section IC.4 applies only when Electronic Throttle Control is used
An Electronic Throttle Control (ETC) system may be used. This is a device or system which
may change the engine throttle setting based on various inputs.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.3.3.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: IC.3.3.3  Failure of any component of the throttle system must not prevent the throttle returning to the closed position.

rule_text: The electronic throttle must automatically close (return to idle) when power is removed.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.1.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
IC.4.1.1
General Design
The electronic throttle must automatically close (return to idle) when power is removed. 
The electronic throttle must use minimum two sources of energy capable of returning the
throttle to the idle position.

rule_text:
The electronic throttle must use minimum two sources of energy capable of returning the throttle to the idle position.
a. One of the sources may be the device (such as a DC motor) that normally actuates the
throttle
b. The other device(s) must be a throttle return spring that can return the throttle to the
idle position if loss of actuator power occurs.
c. Springs in the TPS are not acceptable throttle return springs

response:
IC.4.1.3 

General Design
The electronic throttle must automatically close (return to idle) when power is removed. 
The electronic throttle must use minimum two sources of energy capable of returning the
throttle to the idle position. 
a. One of the sources may be the device (such as a DC motor) that normally actuates the
throttle
b. The other device(s) must be a throttle return spring that can return the throttle to the
idle position if loss of actuator power occurs. 
c.  Springs in the TPS are not acceptable throttle return springs
The ETC system may blip the throttle during downshifts when proven that unintended
acceleration can be avoided. The functional analysis must be documented in the ETC Systems
Form.

rule_text:
When an analogue signal is used, the TPSs will be considered to have failed when they achieve an open circuit or short circuit condition which generates a signal outside of the normal
operating range, for example <0.5 V or >4.5 V.
The circuitry used to evaluate the sensor must use pull down or pull up resistors to ensure
that open circuit signals result in a failure being detected.

rule_text:
When any kind of digital data transmission is used to transmit the TPS signal, a. The ETC Systems Form must contain a detailed description of all the potential failure
modes that can occur, the strategy that is used to detect these failures and the tests that
have been conducted to prove that the detection strategy works.
b. The failures to be considered must include but are not limited to the failure of the TPS,
TPS signals being out of range, corruption of the message and loss of messages and the
associated time outs.

rule_text:
Brakes and Throttle Position a. The power to the electronic throttle must be shut down if the mechanical brakes are
actuated and the TPS signals that the throttle is open by more than a permitted amount
for more than one second.
b. An interval of one second is allowed for the throttle to close (return to idle). Failure to
achieve this in the required interval must result in immediate shut down of fuel flow and
the ignition system.
c. The permitted relationship between BSE and TPS may be defined by the team using a
table. This functionality must be demonstrated at Technical Inspection.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.7.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
IC.4.7.1  Brakes and Throttle Position
a. The power to the electronic throttle must be shut down if the mechanical brakes are
actuated and the TPS signals that the throttle is open by more than a permitted amount
for more than one second. 
b. An interval of one second is allowed for the throttle to close (return to idle). Failure to
achieve this in the required interval must result in immediate shut down of fuel flow and
the ignition system.

rule_text:
Throttle Position vs Target a. The power to the electronic throttle must be immediately shut down, if throttle position
differs by more than 10% from the expected target TPS position for more than one
second.
b. An interval of one second is allowed for the difference to reduce to less than 10%, failure
to achieve this in the required interval must result in immediate shut down of fuel flow
and the ignition system.
c. An error in TPS position and the resultant system shutdown must be demonstrated at
Technical Inspection.
Teams must have a method to demonstrate that the actions in IC.4.7.2.b above are met.
System states displayed using calibration software must be accompanied by a detailed
explanation of the control system.

response:
F.4.3.5  Perimeter Shear Test
a. The Perimeter Shear Test must be completed by measuring the force required to push or pull a 25 mm diameter flat punch through a flat laminate sample. 
b. The sample must: 
•  Measure 100 mm x 100 mm minimum
•  Have core and skin thicknesses identical to those used in the actual application
•  Be manufactured using the same materials and processes

c.  The fixture must support the entire sample except for a 32 mm hole aligned coaxially with the punch. 
d. The sample must not be clamped to the fixture
e. The edge of the punch and hole in the fixture may include an optional fillet up to a maximum radius of 1 mm. 
f.  The SES must include force and displacement data and photos of the test setup. 
g. The first peak in the load-deflection curve must be used to determine the skin shear strength; this may be less than the minimum force required by F.7.3.3 / F.7.5.5
h. The maximum force recorded must meet the requirements of F.7.3.3 / F.7.5.5.

rule_text:
All Fuel Tanks must have a Fuel Filler Neck which must be: a. Minimum 35 mm inner diameter at any point between the Fuel Tank and the Fuel Filler
cap

rule_text:
The Fuel Filler Neck must be accompanied by a clear fuel resistant sight tube for reading the fuel level which must be:
a. Visible vertical height: 125 mm minimum
b. Inside diameter: 6 mm minimum
c. Above the top surface of the Fuel Tank
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.5.4.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
IC.5.4.3 The Fuel Filler Neck must be accompanied by a clear fuel resistant sight tube for reading the fuel level which must be: 
a. Visible vertical height: 125 mm minimum
b. Inside diameter: 6 mm minimum
c. Above the top surface of the Fuel Tank.

rule_text: A clear Fuel Filler Neck tube may be used as a sight tube, subject to approval by a Rules Question or technical inspectors at the event.

rule_text:
Fuel Level Line - A permanent, non movable fuel level line must be located between 12 mm and 25 mm below the top of the visible portion of the sight tube.
This line will be used as the fill line for the Tilt Test, and before and after Endurance to measure
the amount of fuel used during the Endurance Event.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.5.4.5 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
IC.5.4.5  Fuel Level Line - A permanent non movable fuel level line must be located between 12 mm
and 25 mm below the top of the visible portion of the sight tube. 

This line will be used as the fill line for the Tilt Test and before and after Endurance to measure
the amount of fuel used during the Endurance Event.

rule_text:
The sight tube and fuel level line must be clearly visible to two individuals (one to fill the tank, the other to visually verify fill) without the need of assistance (artificial lighting, magnifiers,
etc) or the need to remove any parts (body panels, etc).

rule_text:
The individual filling the tank must have complete direct access to the filler neck opening with a standard two gallon gas can assembly.
The gas can is minimum 25 cm wide x 25 cm deep x 35 cm high, with a 25 cm spout at the top

rule_text: All fuel vent lines must have a check valve to prevent fuel leakage when the tank is inverted.

Venting Systems

rule_text: Fuel lines must be securely attached to the vehicle and/or engine.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.5.7.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
F.5.7.1
Front Hoop 
The Front Hoop must be constructed of closed section metal tubing meeting F.3.2.1.c
With proper Triangulation the Front Hoop may be fabricated from more than one piece of
tubing
The Front Hoop must extend from the lowest Frame Member on one side of the Frame up 
over and down to the lowest Frame Member on the other side of the Frame. 
The top-most surface of the Front Hoop must be no lower than the top of the steering wheel
in any angular position. See figure following F.5.9.6 below 
The Front Hoop must be no more than 250 mm forward of the steering wheel. 
This distance is measured horizontally on the vehicle centerline from the rear surface of the
Front Hoop to the forward most surface of the steering wheel rim with the steering in the
straight ahead position. 
In side view any part of the Front Hoop above the Upper Side Impact Structure must be
inclined less than 20° from the vertical. 
A Front Hoop that is not steel must have a 4 mm hole drilled in a location to access during
Technical Inspection.

rule_text: All fuel lines must be shielded from possible rotating equipment failure or collision damage.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.5.7.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: The Front Hoop must extend from the lowest Frame Member on one side of the Frame up over and down to the lowest Frame Member on the other side of the Frame.

rule_text: Plastic fuel lines between the fuel tank and the engine (supply and return) are prohibited.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.5.7.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
F.5.7.3

The Front Hoop must be constructed of closed section metal tubing meeting F.3.2.1.c
With proper Triangulation the Front Hoop may be fabricated from more than one piece of
tubing
The Front Hoop must extend from the lowest Frame Member on one side of the Frame up
over and down to the lowest Frame Member on the other side of the Frame.
The top-most surface of the Front Hoop must be no lower than the top of the steering wheel
in any angular position. See figure following F.5.9.6 below
The Front Hoop must be no more than 250 mm forward of the steering wheel.
This distance is measured horizontally on the vehicle centerline from the rear surface of the
Front Hoop to the forward most surface of the steering wheel rim with the steering in the
straight ahead position.
In side view any part of the Front Hoop above the Upper Side Impact Structure must be
inclined less than 20° from the vertical.
A Front Hoop that is not steel must have a 4 mm hole drilled in a location to access during
Technical Inspection.

rule_text:
Low Pressure fuel injection systems are those functioning at a pressure below 10 Bar. Most
Port Fuel Injected (PFI) fuel systems are low pressure.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.6.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
GR.6.1  Definition of Terms 
•  Must - designates a requirement 
•  Must NOT - designates a prohibition or restriction 
•  Should - gives an expectation 
•  May - gives permission not a requirement and not a recommendation.

rule_text:
Any Low Pressure flexible fuel lines must be one of: • Metal braided hose with threaded fittings (crimped on or reusable)
• Reinforced rubber hose with some form of abrasion resistant protection

rule_text:
Fuel rail and mounting requirements: a. Unmodified OEM Fuel Rails are acceptable, regardless of material.
b. Non OEM fuel rails made from plastic, carbon fiber or rapid prototyping flammable
materials are prohibited.
c. The fuel rail must be securely attached to the manifold, engine block or cylinder head
with brackets and mechanical fasteners.
Hose clamps, plastic ties, or safety wires do not meet this requirement.
d. Threaded fasteners used to secure the fuel rail are Critical Fasteners, see T.8.2
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.6.1.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
IC.6.1.2  Fuel rail and mounting requirements: 
a. Unmodified OEM Fuel Rails are acceptable regardless of material. 
b. Non OEM fuel rails made from plastic, carbon fiber or rapid prototyping flammable materials are prohibited. 
c.  The fuel rail must be securely attached to the manifold engine block or cylinder head with brackets and mechanical fasteners. Hose clamps, plastic ties, or safety wires do not meet this requirement. 
d. Threaded fasteners used to secure the fuel rail are Critical Fasteners see T.8.2.

rule_text:
Definitions a. High Pressure fuel systems - those functioning at 10 Bar pressure or above
b. Direct Injection fuel systems - where the injection occurs directly into the combustion
system
Direct Injection systems often utilize a low pressure electric fuel pump and high pressure
mechanical “boost” pump driven off the engine.
c. High Pressure Fuel Lines - those between the boost pump and injectors
d. Low Pressure Fuel Lines - from the electric supply pump to the boost pump
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.6.2.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
IC.6.2.1 
High Pressure Injection (HPI) / Direct Injection (DI) 
Definitions
a. High Pressure fuel systems - those functioning at 10 Bar pressure or above
b. Direct Injection fuel systems - where the injection occurs directly into the combustion
system
Direct Injection systems often utilize a low pressure electric fuel pump and high pressure
mechanical “boost” pump driven off the engine.

rule_text:
All High Pressure Fuel Lines must: a. Be stainless steel rigid line or Aeroquip FC807 smooth bore PTFE hose with stainless steel
reinforcement and visible Nomex tracer yarn. Equivalent products may be used with
prior approval.
b. Not incorporate elastomeric seals
c. Be rigidly connected every 100 mm by mechanical fasteners to structural engine
components such as cylinder heads or block

rule_text:
Fuel rail mounting requirements: a. The fuel rail must be securely attached to the engine block or cylinder head with brackets
and mechanical fasteners. Hose clamps, plastic ties, or safety wires do not meet this
requirement.
b. The fastening method must be sufficient to hold the fuel rail in place with the maximum
regulated pressure acting on the injector internals and neglecting any assistance from
cylinder pressure acting on the injector tip.
c. Threaded fasteners used to secure the fuel rail are Critical Fasteners, see T.8.2
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.6.2.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
IC.6.2.4 Fuel rail mounting requirements: 
a. The fuel rail must be securely attached to the engine block or cylinder head with brackets and mechanical fasteners. Hose clamps plastic ties or safety wires do not meet this requirement. 
b. The fastening method must be sufficient to hold the fuel rail in place with the maximum regulated pressure acting on the injector internals and neglecting any assistance from cylinder pressure acting on the injector tip. 
c. Threaded fasteners used to secure the fuel rail are Critical Fasteners see T.8.2.

rule_text: High Pressure Fuel Pump – must be rigidly mounted to structural engine components such as the cylinder head or engine block.

rule_text:
Pressure Regulator – must be fitted between the High Pressure and Low Pressure sides of the fuel system in parallel with the DI boost pump. The external regulator must be used even if
the DI boost pump comes equipped with an internal regulator.
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.6.2.6 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response: IC.6.2.6 High Pressure Fuel Pump – must be rigidly mounted to structural engine components such as the cylinder head or engine block. Pressure Regulator – must be fitted between the High Pressure and Low Pressure sides of the fuel system in parallel with the DI boost pump.

rule_text: Configuration and Location - The Primary Master Switch must meet T.9.3
question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.9.3.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
response:
IC.9.3.1
Primary Master Switch
Configuration and Location - The Primary Master Switch must meet T.9.3
Function - the Primary Master Switch must:
a. Disconnect power to ALL electrical circuits including the battery alternator lights fuel pump(s) ignition and electrical controls.
All battery current must flow through this switch
b. Be direct acting not act through a relay or logic.

rule_text:

pump(s), ignition and electrical controls.
All battery current must flow through this switch
b. Be direct acting, not act through a relay or logic.
